CO2 methanation is an effective way for CO2 recycling, and nickel-based catalysts have attracted much attention in this field due to their excellent CH4 selectivity and cost-effectiveness; however, their applications are limited by their suboptimal catalytic activity. In this work, the catalytic activity of Ni-rutile-based catalysts was increased by almost an order of magnitude simply by doping the rutile with Fe. Series characterizations show that three factors that mainly contributed to the improved catalytic performance of the Ni/Fe-Rutile, which are the reduction of the Ni size, the increase of the basic sites, and the inhibition of the encapsulation of the Ni particles by the support. With Fe doping, the OH and oxygen vacancies on the rutile surface were reduced, which made the support difficult to reduce and thus suppressed the encapsulation of Ni by the support. As a result, the number of exposed active sites on the Ni/Fe-Rutile which with a smaller Ni size was further successfully increased, and the catalytic activity was significantly improved. This study provides new ideas for the design of activity-enhanced supported catalysts from the perspective of tuning the metal-support interaction and may be applicable to other reducible oxide-supported metal catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Fe doping Nickel catalyst CO2 methanation Metal−support interaction Catalytic activity Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction The rapid economic development is accompanied by the large-scale consumption of fossil fuels and the massive emission of greenhouse gasses, mainly CO2, which will inevitably cause a more serious greenhouse effect and further aggravate the global warming phenomenon. Therefore, the promotion of large-scale CO2 capture and conversion has become one of the current research hotspots [1–4]. As an important basic carbon source, CO2 can be hydrogenated to produce a more valuable clean fuel CH4, a process known as methanation (i.e. Sabatier reaction), which is now a promising approach to mitigate CO2 emissions [5,6]. However, as CO2 methanation is an exothermic process, the catalyst used typically exhibits poor CH4 selectivity at high temperatures due to the thermodynamics and tends to produce by-product of CO, while at low temperatures it generally exhibits an unsatisfactory CO2 conversion due to the poor catalytic activity for kinetic reasons [7,8]. The development of highly efficient catalysts with excellent methane selectivity is therefore of great importance and has already become one of the main research goals in this field. Ni-based catalysts have attracted a great deal of attention in the context of CO2 methanation due to their exceptional methane selectivity and affordability [9,10]. However, the limited reactivity of conventional Ni-based catalysts, particularly under low-temperature reaction conditions, restricts their application. As such, it is imperative to enhance the catalytic activity of Ni-based catalysts. Considerable efforts are currently being made to achieve this goal, and the strategies can roughly be divided into two categories according to their direct-action target. One is the method that acts directly on the nickel species, which improves the catalytic performance of the catalysts by optimizing the preparation method of the catalysts or by introducing a second active metal to reduce the Ni particle size or to adjust the chemical state of the nickel species [11–16]. For instance, Gennari et al. studied on the Al2O3 supported Ni-CeO2-based catalysts and found that for the CO2 hydrogenation, the catalyst synthesized by simultaneous impregnation of NiO and CeO2 was more active than the catalyst synthesized by successive impregnation. They associated this result with the contribution of both oxygen vacancies and Ni-O-Ce solid solution at the surface, inducing a superior reducibility and more labile moderate basic sites [17]. Moreover, the importance of the Ni-O-Ce on the basicity of the catalyst was also highlighted in the work of Goula et al., which compared the varies sol-gel preparation methods of the Pr-doped CeO2 supported Ni catalyst [18]. The effect of alloying has been investigated by series reports [9,19–22], for example, in the work of Bacariza et al. the catalytic activity of Ni15/USY was effectively improved after Fe introduction. This improvement was attributed to the establishment of stronger Ni-support interactions and the formation of smaller and better dispersed Ni0 particles owning to the presence of Fe-Ni alloys [23]. The other category starts from the support, as numerous studies show that metal-support interactions have a significant influence on the catalytic activity of the nanocatalysts [24–27]. This category is mainly based on doping, compounding, or gas pretreatment of the support to achieve a tuning of the interaction strength between the metal and the support, thus modifying or increasing the exposed active sites on the nickel particles to ultimately improve the catalytic activity of the catalyst [28–30]. For example, in the work of Oni et al., investigated the importance of the synergistic effects between the Ni active sites, the promoter (Pr2O3 and MgO) and the support (MCM-41) on the methanation of CO2. It was found that the inclusion of MgO-Pr2O3 has a positive effect on the catalyst, such as the better Ni dispersion and the increased CO2 adsorption sites, which all benefit the catalytic activities of the catalysts [31]. Another typical example is that in the work of the Bao's group [30], the strength of the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) between Ni species and anatase TiO2 was successfully tuned by pretreating the anatase with ammonia or hydrogen, achieving an order of magnitude increase in catalyst activity and the product shift from all-CO to CH4 dominated. In this work, the catalytic activity of the Ni-rutile based catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation was significantly enhanced by almost an order of magnitude by simply doping the rutile support with Fe. Further studies show that this method of Fe doping has considerably enhanced the Ni-rutile interaction while reducing the content of hydroxyl and oxygen vacancies on the support surface compared to the method of adding Fe by physical grinding, where the former allows the catalyst to maintain a small Ni particle size, while the latter makes the support difficult to reduce, thus inhibiting the encapsulation of Ni by the support to some extent. Finally, the number of active sites exposed on the Ni/Fe-Rutile catalyst increased significantly due to the aforementioned factors, resulting in a marked improvement in the catalytic activity of the catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals were of analytical grade and were used as purchased without further purification unless otherwise specified. Titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4, 99.9 % metal basis), hydrochloric acid (HCl, ACS reagent, 37 %), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 99.99 % metal basis) and ferric oxide (γ-Fe2O3, 10 nm,98 % metal basis) were purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. 2.2 Support synthesis Rutile TiO2 was synthesized by a hydrolysis method [32]. Typically, under ice-water bath conditions, 5 mL of TiCl4 was added into 13 mL of HCl solution (∼37 wt%). Then, the solution volume was increased to 150 mL by adding ultrapure water. After adding a certain mass of γ-Fe2O3, the resulting solution was heated to 60 °C and stirred for 4 h, and then aged for 1 h at room temperature. The precipitates were then filtered, washed several times with ultrapure water to remove Cl− ions and dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. After further calcination of the powder sample at 500 °C under air flow for 4 h, Fe-doped rutile was obtained and denoted Fe-Rutile. The iron-free rutile (i.e. rutile) was synthesized by the same method as that of the Fe-Rutile, except that no γ-Fe2O3 was added in the process. In addition, for comparison, some rutile was mixed with γ-Fe2O3 and ground in an agate mortar for 15 min. The mixed powder was further calcined at 500 °C for 4 h under air flow and labeled as grind-FeR. The actual Fe content of Fe-Rutile and grind-FeR is the same, with a value of 0.1 wt%. In some cases, Fe-Rutile and grind-FeR were further reduced at 500 °C for 2 h under 10 vol% H2-Ar flow and labelled as Fe-Rutile-H and grind-FeR-H, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst preparation Ni species were introduced onto the support by a wet-impregnation method with a target loading of 10 wt% [33]. Typically, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.55 g) was dissolved in 30 mL of ultrapure water, and then 1.0 g of support was added to this solution. After stirring for 1 h at room temperature, the suspension was transferred to a 60 °C water bath and stirred continuously until the water was completely evaporated. The obtained sample was further calcined under air flow at 500 °C for 4 h and denoted NiO/Support (Support = Rutile, Fe-Rutile and grind-FeR). The NiO/Support was further reduced at 500 °C for 2 h under H2 flow and the resulting catalysts were denoted as Ni/Support. 2.4 Catalyst characterization Actual content of Ni and Fe were determined by an inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) using an IRIS Intrepid II XSP instrument (Thermo Electron Corporation). X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer with a Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) monochromatic radiation source from 10° to 80° at a scan rate of 10°/min. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) analyses were performed with a JEOL JEM-2100F microscope. Before microscopy examination, the catalysts were ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol and then a drop of the solution was put onto microgrid carbon polymer supported on copper grid. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm was performed on a Micromeritics TriStar II 3020 at −196 °C. Prior to the experiments, freshly reduced Ni/support samples (∼100 mg) were degassed under vacuum at 350 °C for 4 h to completely clean the surface. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method and the Barrett-Joynerr-Halenda desorption isotherm model were used to determine the specific surface area and pore volume respectively. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on a chemisorption instrument (Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920). 50 mg of calcined NiO/Support sample was pre-treated at 200 °C under a flow of Ar (30 mL/min) for 1 h in a quartz tube reactor. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, a gas flow of 5 vol% H2/Ar (30 mL/min) was introduced, and the sample was heated up to 700 °C on a ramp of 10 °C/min, with the effluents monitored by an on-line mass spectrometer. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) characterizations were also performed out on the chemisorption instrument (Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920). First, NiO/Support samples were treated under an Ar atmosphere at 200 °C for 1 h to obtain the clean surfaces. They were then reduced at 500 °C for 2 h under 10 vol% H2-Ar flow. After reduction, the gas was switched to Ar and maintained for 1 h. Then the system was cooled to ∼50 °C and a CO2 flow was introduced for 30 min for adsorption, which followed by a He treatment for 30 min to remove the physically adsorbed gas. Finally, the temperature was continuously increased to 700 °C on a ramp of 10 °C/min and the desorbed CO2 was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted on a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi system with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.68 eV). The binding energy was calibrated by contamination carbon C 1 s peak (284.6 eV) as a reference. For the spectra of the three Ni samples, before the test, the samples of NiO/Support (Support = Fe-Rutile, Rutile and grind-FeR) were reduced at 500 °C in H2 atmosphere for 2 h in a microquartz tube reactor and were stored in the same tube until the XPS measurements were performed. Thermogravimetric-Differential Thermal Analysis (TG-DTG) was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449F5 (Germany) operated under 20 vol% O2/80 vol% N2 flow with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. 2.5 Activity test The catalytic performance of the catalysts was evaluated on a fixed bed reactor operating at atmospheric pressure. The system is also equipped with a water trap, which is located between the fixed bed reactor and the gas chromatography (Panna A91 Plus), is used to remove water vapor (generated by the reaction) from the gas stream. The catalyst which diluted with an equal amount of SiO2 powder (40–60 mesh) was loaded in the quartz reactor and reduced in situ at 500 °C under a flow of 10 vol% H2-Ar (30 mL/min) for 2 h at atmospheric pressure prior to reaction. A pre-mixed stream of CO2, H2, and Ar (4 vol% H2 + 1 vol% CO2 + 95 vol% Ar; 50 mL/min, with a weight hourly space velocity of 75,000 ml gcat −1 h−1) was used as the feed gas, and Ar was used as the carrier gas for online gas chromatograph analysis. Hayesep Q and 5A molecular sieve-packed columns connected to the TCD were used for the quantification CO, CO2, and CH4. CO2 conversion was calculated on a carbon atom basis, i.e. C O 2 conversion ( % ) = [ C O 2 ] in − [ C O 2 ] out [ C O 2 ] in × 100 % CH4 selectivity and CO selectivity were calculated as the following: C H 4 selectivity ( % ) = [ C H 4 ] out [ C H 4 ] out + [ CO ] out × 100 % CO selectivity ( % ) = 100 − C H 4 selectivity ( % ) Where, [ C O 2 ] in and [ C O 2 ] out represent the moles of CO2 in the feed and effluent, respectively, and [ C H 4 ] out and [ CO ] out represent the moles of CH4 and CO in the effluent, respectively. 3 Results and discussion The XRD patterns of the series catalysts after reduction are presented in Fig. 1 . All the XRD patterns of the three freshly reduced Ni samples mainly show the characteristic diffraction peaks of rutile (Fig. 1a), indicating that the rutile form of TiO2 has been successfully prepared, and the introduction of Fe species has not affected the crystalline structure of the support. For the Ni/Fe-Rutile and Ni/grind-FeR, no diffraction peaks assigned to Fe species are detected as the content of Fe species is too low (0.1 wt%, Table 1 ) to reach the detection limit of the XRD. In addition to the rutile patterns, diffraction peaks of Ni (111) located at 2θ = 44.5° are observed in all samples, indicating that all the Ni species have been reduced to metallic Ni. It is noticeable that the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the samples are different and the Ni/Fe-Rutile has the widest FWHM. According to the Scherrer equation, the widest FWHM demonstrates the smallest calculated particle size. Therefore, the above results indicate that the Ni/Fe-Rutile sample has the smallest Ni particle size. This was further confirmed by the electron microscopy results as shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. S1. The Ni/Fe-Rutile sample has the smallest Ni particle size, with a mean diameter of 31 nm, much smaller than the 44 and 47 nm of the Ni/grind-FeR and Ni/Rutile samples, respectively. We also note that for the two samples with added Fe, Ni/Fe-Rutile and Ni/grind-FeR, although the Fe species are highly dispersed in both samples and with the same content, there is a large difference in their Ni particle sizes (31 vs. 44 nm), suggesting that the method of Fe introduction has an important effect on the dispersion of nickel species, although it does not affect the dispersion of Fe species. The effect of Fe addition on the specific surface area (SSA) and porosity of the samples was also studied and the results are shown in Fig. S2 and Table 1. All the three freshly reduced Ni catalysts exhibit the same type IV isotherm with H3 hysteresis loops, which indicating wedge/slit shaped pores [17,34,35]. There is no obvious effect of Fe inclusion on the pore structure of the Ni-TiO2, and this result was entirely predictable, since the rutile-TiO2 we prepared is not a porous material (as further shown by the pore volume in the Table 1). The BET SSA of Ni/Fe-Rutile is almost the same as that of Ni/Rutile (12.6 vs. 12.4 m2 g−1), suggesting that the Fe doping did not affect the rutile crystallinity, which is consistent with the results of the XRD patterns where the diffraction peaks of rutile (110) at 2θ = 27.4° of the three Ni/Support are almost the same (Fig. 1a). For the Ni/grind-FeR sample, the SSA is slightly higher than for the other two (19.2 vs. ∼12 m2 g−1). This may be due to the grinding process which has further broken up the rutile particles. Overall, there is no obvious difference between the three Ni/Support samples in terms of the BET parameters (SSA, pore volume and type, etc.), so these factors have little influence on the Ni species size/distribution and further on the catalytic performance. For supported catalysts, the size of the metal particles is generally one of the most important factors in determining the catalytic performance, since the active sites of the catalysts are usually located on the surface of the metal particles [36,37]. In our case, the catalytic performance of the series Ni/Support catalysts for CO2 methanation is shown in Fig. 3 and Fig. S3. All three catalysts exhibited excellent reaction stability, and as expected, their catalytic activities differed significantly. Specifically, at a test temperature of 360 °C, the Ni/Rutile sample with the largest Ni size exhibited the lowest catalytic activity with a CO2 conversion of only 4 % and a CH4 selectivity of 100 %. In contrast, the Ni/Fe-Rutile with the smallest Ni size showed a CO2 conversion of 34.6 % with 100 % CH4 selectivity, almost achieved an order of magnitude increase in CO2 conversion compared to that of the Ni/Rutile. For a more accurate comparison, all CO2 conversions at 360 °C of the catalysts were controlled below 20 % by adjusting the catalyst weight and feed gas flow rate, and the corresponding TOF values were calculated, Table 1. The TOF value of the Ni/Fe-Rutile is 0.06 s−1, which is six times higher than the 0.01 s−1 of the Ni/Rutile, indicating a significantly improved catalytic activity of the Ni/Fe-Rutile. It should be noted that although Fe is generally an active metal for the CO2 methanation, in our experiments, the newly reduced Fe-Rutile-H support is inactive under this reaction condition due to its very low Fe content (0.1 wt%, Table 1), suggesting that the enhanced activity of Fe introduction on Ni-based catalysts is not simply in the form of Fe as a second active metal. It is worth noting that after introducing Fe into the Ni catalyst by a physical grinding, the Ni/grind-FeR catalyst which with a mean Ni size of 44 nm shows a CO2 conversion of 15.4 % at 360 °C (100 % CH4 selectivity), which is about six times higher than that of the Ni/Rutile which with a similar Ni size (47 nm). This suggests that there are factors other than particle size that strongly influence the catalytic performance of the catalysts. In order to explore these factors and to further investigate the causes of the difference in Ni particle size of the catalysts, a series of characterization of the samples was carried out. To investigate the reducibility of Ni species on the three NiO/Support, hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurement was performed. As shown in Fig. 4a , for each of the Ni samples, there are three peaks falling in the range of 300∼500 °C, which are attributed to the reduction of NiO species with different interaction strengths with the support [38,39]. For the NiO/grind-FeR, the overall peak shape is similar to that of the NiO/Rutile sample, but the peak positions are slightly shifted towards higher temperatures, indicating that the Ni species are more difficult to reduce after the addition of Fe species to the sample [39]. For the NiO/Fe-Rutile sample, the same peak positions are observed as for the NiO/grind-FeR sample, accompanied by an increase in the proportion of the high temperature peak (peak III, located at 451 °C), indicating that this sample has the strongest Ni-support interaction among the three samples. This may be one of the main reasons that this sample has the smallest Ni particle size after the 500 °C reduction. In conclusion, after the high temperature reduction at 500 °C, the nickel species on all three samples were basically reduced to metallic nickel, while the addition of Fe species and the addition method affected the interaction strength between Ni and the support, ultimately leading to the differences in the Ni particle sizes of each catalyst. CO2-TPD was used to assess the strength of the active centres for CO2 adsorption, and the influence of Fe addition on the CO2 activation in the reaction. The CO2-TPD profiles of the freshly reduced Ni samples are shown in Fig. 4b. The basicity calculated from the obtained profiles is presented in Table S1. All the CO2-TPD profiles can be classified into weak basic sites (< 200 °C), moderate strong basic sites (200∼300 °C) and strong basic sites (> 300 °C), depending on the observed CO2 desorption temperature, and corresponding to the surface hydroxyl group, Lewis acid-base pairs, and low coordination surface O2−, respectively [40–42]. The samples of Ni/Fe-Rutile and Ni/grind-FeR showed a significant increase in CO2 desorption peak intensity compared to the Ni/Rutile in all three intervals, specifically, the total basicity of Ni/Fe-Rutile and Ni/grind-FeR is 2.4 and 3.8 times of that of the Ni/Rutile, respectively. The increase in total basicity should be attributed to the addition of Fe, similar effect has been observed in previous reports [23,40]. The greater increase in Ni/grind-FeR compared to Ni/Fe-Rutile is attributed to the higher Fe content on the surface of Ni/grind-FeR, although the Fe content is the same in the two samples: in the former, where Fe is added by physical milling, all of the Fe is present on the surface of the supports, whereas in the latter, where Fe is added by doping, some of the Fe is buried within the bulk rutile. Although the mechanism of CO2 conversion to methane is still controversial, it is generally accepted that the increase in basic sites, especially those of moderate strength, facilitates CO2 conversion [42,43]. Thus, in our case, the increase in activity of Ni/Fe-Rutile and Ni/grind-FeR was also related to the increase in basic sites induced by the addition of Fe. For example, this effect of Fe is likely to be one of the main reasons for the significant increase in activity of Ni/grind-FeR catalysts with the largest Ni particle size compared to Ni/Rutile catalysts. To further characterize the valence state of the nickel species of each sample, XPS measurements were performed on the Ni/Support samples. As shown in Fig. 5a , the XPS Ni 2p3/2 spectra of all three samples are dominated by the metallic Ni (Ni0) signal located at ∼852.5 eV, while a weak signal of Ni2+ at ∼853.7 eV is also detected, which should be attributed to the interfacial Ni species [44,45]. The percentage of Ni0 is almost identical in all three spectra, ranging from 81 % to 84 % (Table 1). Therefore, the influence of the Ni valence variation on the different activities of each catalyst can be largely eliminated. However, it is noteworthy that there is a significant difference in the XPS Ni 2p3/2 area between the catalysts, with the Ni/Fe-Rutile sample exhibiting the largest Ni 2p3/2 area and Ni/Ti ratio. This indicates a larger number of exposed nickel species on the Ni/Fe-Rutile sample. The discrepancy in the Ni 2p3/2 areas observed here cannot solely be attributed to the difference in Ni particle size between the samples. This is evidenced by the fact that the theoretical values of the Ni 2p3/2 areas for Ni/grind-FeR and Ni/Rutile, calculated based on their respective particle sizes, far exceed their actual measured values (Fig. 5c and Table S2, details can be found in Supplementary Information). Particularly for the Ni/Rutile, the measured value is only 50 % of the theoretical value (0.33 vs. 0.66, both normalized to the value of Ni/Fe-Rutile). In view of this, the possibility that strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) has occurred in the samples is considered, since the metal encapsulation by the support accompanying SMSI would lead to a decrease in the content of metal species detectable by XPS, and the TiO2-supported Ni-based catalyst after reduction at 500 °C is a typical SMSI catalyst [46–50]. To verify this speculation, the Ni particles located at the edge of the supports in the three samples were characterized by TEM to ascertain whether the surface of the Ni particles was encapsulated by the supports or not [51]. As shown in Fig. S4 and Fig. 6 , high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images show that thin encapsulation layers are visible on the surface of the Ni particles in all samples, while STEM-EDX elemental maps show that Ti and O signals can be detected on the surface of the Ni particles, and Fe signals are also seen in the samples containing Fe. These results indicate that after reduction at 500 °C, a support encapsulation layer is present on the Ni surface over the three samples. However, it should be noted that there are no results showing that the chemisorption capacity of the catalysts for CO or H2 was dramatically decreased, which is the essential feature of SMSI. Therefore, we consider that there is a metal-support strong interaction (MSSI) on the catalyst system and, of course, it is most likely to be the SMSI effect. The degree of difference between the theoretical Ni 2p3/2 area and the actual Ni 2p3/2 area varies between the samples, suggesting that the three samples differ in the degree of encapsulation of the Ni particles by the support: the greater the difference, the more pronounced the encapsulation. What causes the difference in encapsulation? It is generally accepted that the coating layers on the metal particles, which with a reducible transition metal oxide as support, are formed from the partially reduced support [52,53], i.e. the reduction of the support is one of the prerequisites for the onset of encapsulation. In our samples, however, the degree of support reduction is clearly different, as evidenced by the fact that in the Ti 2p3/2 spectra of Ni/grind-FeR and Ni/Rutile, in addition to the Ti4+ peak at 458.8 eV, a weak Ti3+ peak at 457 eV is detected [54], whereas, in the spectrum of the Ni/Fe-Rutile, although the binding energy (B.E.) of Ti 2p3/2 was shifted to 458.1 eV, no Ti3+ signal was detected (Fig. 5b). In short, the support in the Ni/grind-FeR and Ni/Rutile samples was partially reduced, whereas no significant support reduction occurred in the Ni/Fe-Rutile sample, leading to the difference in the encapsulation degree of the samples. What then accounts for the differences in support reduction between the samples, especially for the samples Ni/Fe-Rutile and Ni/grind-FeR, which are identical regardless of element type and element content? This was explained by the XPS results of the calcined grind-FeR and Fe-Rutile. The Ti 2p and Fe 2p spectra of the two supports are basically the same (Fig. S5a-b), but their O 1 s spectra are significantly different (Fig. S5c and Table S3). The grind-FeR spectrum shows that there is a large amount of hydroxyl groups (-OH, 530.7 eV, 21 %) and surface oxygen vacancies (Ov, 532.1 eV, 5 %) in addition to the lattice O (Olatt, 529.6 eV) [55,56]. However, for the Fe-Rutile spectrum, not only contains less -OH (9 %), but also no Ov are detected. Generally, the surface Ov and -OH on the surface of metal oxides facilitate the reduction of metal oxides [57,58]. Therefore, for the Ni/Fe-Rutile, the lower Ov and -OH content resulted in the support being more difficult to reduce, and the catalyst ultimately exhibited a lower encapsulation degree of the Ni particles, with more Ni sites exposed on the surface, which further enhanced the catalytic performance of the catalysts. Finally, we carried out a series of characterizations on the spent catalysts after CO2 methanation, as there is a risk that the catalysts may undergo sintering [59], SMSI fading (i.e. encapsulation retreat) [60] and other changes during the reaction process that can seriously affect the catalytic performance. As shown in Figs. S6 and S7, the Ni particles on the three catalysts are still encapsulated by the support, so under the stabilizing effect of this encapsulation, the Ni particles did not undergo significant sintering during the reaction (Fig. S8 shows that the Ni particle size of the catalysts did not change significantly compared to those before the reaction). These results are consistent with the excellent stability performance of the three catalysts during the reaction (Fig. 3b). We also investigated the possible presence of carbon deposition, as it is an important factor affecting the catalytic stability of the catalysts. As shown in the Fig. 7 , the TG-DTG profiles of all samples showed the same tendency of variation: First a slightly decreasing trend before 200 °C and then an increasing trend at around 300 °C, after which the profiles decrease again from a temperature of 600 °C. The first decrease is due to the desorption of the adsorbed H2O. The mass increase in the range of 300 to 600 °C is caused by the oxidation of metallic Ni (from Ni to NiO, and finally to Ni2O3) in the catalyst at high temperatures in air [61,62]. The second decrease can be attributed to the formation of CO2 by oxidation of the carbon species deposited on the catalysts, and the peak temperatures of the weight loss rate of the deposited carbon are around 700–750 °C, indicating the formation of graphitic carbon deposited on the catalyst surface [61,63]. Overall, the TG-DTG profiles of the spent catalysts are basically the same, and the weight loss for them was insignificant and did not differ much from each other (0.7 %∼1.8 %), i.e. the effect of carbon deposition on the difference in activity of each catalyst can be negligible. 4 Conclusion In summary, Ni/Fe-Rutile catalyst was prepared by doping Fe into the rutile support, and its catalytic activity for CO2 methanation was significantly improved compared to other Ni catalysts which supported on an iron-free rutile support and a physical grinded Fe-Rutile support. It was found that the addition of Fe species during the rutile support preparation effectively improved the content of basic sites and enhanced the Ni/support interaction, resulting in a Ni/Fe-rutile catalyst with smaller Ni size and increased basic sites, all of which are beneficial to the catalytic activity. On the other hand, the addition of Fe has reduced the content of -OH and Ov on the support surface, thus inhibiting the reduction of the support, so that the catalyst is in a weak MSSI state and with a lower degree of encapsulation of the Ni particle. Under these effects of the Fe addition, the active sites of the Ni/Fe-Rutile catalyst were significantly increased, resulting in a significantly improved catalytic activity of the catalyst. In this study, it was found that a simple Fe doping method could be used to adjust the metal-support interaction of the catalyst system and consequently enhance the catalytic activity, which may provide a new idea for the design and preparation of new highly active supported catalysts. coredata.dc:description: CO2 methanation is an effective way for CO2 recycling, and nickel-based catalysts have attracted much attention in this field due to their excellent CH4 selectivity and cost-effectiveness; however, their applications are limited by their suboptimal catalytic activity. In this work, the catalytic activity of Ni-rutile-based catalysts was increased by almost an order of magnitude simply by doping the rutile with Fe. Series characterizations show that three factors that mainly contributed to the improved catalytic performance of the Ni/Fe-Rutile, which are the reduction of the Ni size, the increase of the basic sites, and the inhibition of the encapsulation of the Ni particles by the support. With Fe doping, the OH and oxygen vacancies on the rutile surface were reduced, which made the support difficult to reduce and thus suppressed the encapsulation of Ni by the support. As a result, the number of exposed active sites on the Ni/Fe-Rutile which with a smaller Ni size was further successfully increased, and the catalytic activity was significantly improved. This study provides new ideas for the design of activity-enhanced supported catalysts from the perspective of tuning the metal-support interaction and may be applicable to other reducible oxide-supported metal catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced CO2 methanation activity of Ni-Rutile-based catalyst by tuning the metal−support interaction with Fe doping
